questions.question: After identifying a file signature in a traffic dump, what is the next step in reconstructing the file?

answers.a: Ignore the file and look for another signature
answers.b: Export the raw data bytes associated with the signature
answers.c: Rename the file with the correct extension
answers.d: Run a virus scan on the file

explanations.a: Ignoring the file defeats the purpose of reconstruction.
explanations.b: Correct. After identifying the file signature, you should export the raw data bytes.
explanations.c: Renaming is not sufficient for reconstructing the file.
explanations.d: Running a virus scan is good practice but not the next step in reconstruction.

questions.question: When fixing a corrupted image header, why is it important to use the correct file signature?

answers.a: The correct signature ensures that the file opens with the right application
answers.b: It adds extra layers of security to the file
answers.d: It makes the file easier to share online

explanations.a: Using the correct file signature ensures that the operating system recognizes the file type and opens it with the appropriate application.
explanations.b: File signatures do not enhance security.
explanations.c: File signatures do not alter the file size.
explanations.d: File signatures are unrelated to sharing capabilities.

questions.question: In the context of file carving from an image file, what does the 'offset' refer to?

answers.a: The size of the embedded file
answers.b: The location of the embedded file within the image
answers.c: The file extension of the embedded file
answers.d: The type of compression used on the embedded file

explanations.a: Offset refers to the position within the file, not its size.
explanations.b: Correct. The offset is the position within the image file where the embedded file starts.
explanations.c: Offset does not relate to the file extension.
explanations.d: Offset is not related to compression.

questions.question: Which part of a file typically contains the file signature?

explanations.a: Footers may contain other information, but file signatures are generally at the beginning.
explanations.b: The middle of a file usually contains data, not identification info.
explanations.c: Correct. File signatures are typically located in the header section of a file.
explanations.d: File names can be misleading and are not reliable for type identification.

questions.question: What makes file signatures a reliable method for identifying file types?

answers.a: They are customizable and change with user preference
answers.b: They are embedded in every file and follow standard patterns

explanations.a: Signatures are not meant to be changed by users.
explanations.b: Correct. File signatures follow a standard format that helps reliably identify file types.
explanations.c: File extensions can be misleading and are not part of the signature.
explanations.d: Signatures are not encrypted; they are meant to be identifiable.
